content.description:
Start up a thin seam in a Columnar Joint to a bolt, then up to a two bolt anchor on a ledge.

Pitch 2, follows 4 bolts through an overhanging jug haul to another ledge. Build an anchor at the ledge. The place to do so is obvious.

Pitch 3 climbs various bullshit to the top of the formation.
content.protection: 1 bolt. Gear to 3" emphasis on small stuff.
content.location: Located on the steep West Face of Lone Rock. Right of the Eagles Nest.

content.description:
Climb up past two bolts on a knobby face to a rock scar and small ledge. Climb a thin crack in a dihedral to a roof protected by a pin and gear. Climb over the roof on hidden jugs past a bolt to a two bolt anchor.

Pitch 2 climbs bullshit to the top or rappel from here.
content.location: On the far right side of the North Face of Lone Rock. Look for a left facing dihedral and a big rock scar that marks its start.

content.description: Look for the large white slab to the right of the "alcove". Bottomed out crack and good face holds leads to ledge and first belay (old hardware). Continue towards the projecting rock formation at head left to second anchor (2 bolts). Finish small roof and crack to summit.

An obvious tube shaped depression located on the far right side of the North Face of Lone Rock.

Climb up inside the tube on big holds and steep rock past 4 bolts. The crux comes just after the 3rd bolt and is decently protected. The majority of the route never peaks above 5.7 . After the last bolt there are some gear placements that protect a few awkward moves.

The summit register says it all. " Leave your Nuts, Bring your Balls"!
content.location: Located on the far right side of the North Face in an obvious tube shaped depression in the wall.

content.description: Climb the prominent East Ridge of Lone Rock Spire. There are many ways to start this route but they all will eventually bottle neck on the ridge and end in the same place. Most options are similar in difficulty and protection. This route can be done in one long pitch if mindful of rope drag.
content.location: On the obvious east rib of Lone Rock. It sticks out like a sore thumb.
